stream_context.summary: Kaze models and playtests a new icy, surreal castle area in Course 13 on real N64 hardware, discusses recent performance/bug-fix work (including N64-only issues), and pauses mid-stream to host/live-react to the annual F3 fan-game showcase. He also shares personal life updates (newborn daughter) and explains his strategy for communicating progress without over-spoiling the hack.
stream_context.significance_reason: He states Course 13 is already well underway, hopes to finish it within ~a month, and says only two levels would remain afterward—an endgame production milestone. The stream also includes concrete release/legality plans (no cartridge sales; souvenir box/inlet) and significant personal context (newborn).

findings.summary: Kaze shares that his daughter was born five days earlier, that her name is Reyna, and that Zeina’s mom is currently helping with childcare—making the workload feel manageable, though he notes it’s likely more work for Zeina than for him.

Kaze says this stream’s main work is on Course 13, which is already “pretty far into it,” and he hopes to finish it within the next month; after that, only two levels would be missing from the project.
He reports spending the prior week on bug fixing and “minuscule performance tweaks,” and says he’s almost done with his to-do list for bugs/performance issues.

He demonstrates quick iteration on real N64 via a one-button workflow to switch from emulator/dev environment to capture-card N64 output, using it to validate behavior/performance and visual settings like anti-aliasing.

A pipe that previously never worked on N64 now functions after a recent fix, but he immediately encounters additional N64-specific oddities (a timer running far too fast) and notes uncertainty about PAL timing and unlimited-FPS edge cases.

He observes camera problems on N64 in a very large area (visual artifacts tied to framebuffer not being cleared and camera misbehavior), concluding the level may be too big and that he may need to “invent a solution,” though he postpones it for now.

While playtesting a snowman-path platforming section, he decides some obstacle placements and wall-kick alignments feel awkward, and he simplifies the sequence by bringing elements inward—partly to avoid triggering the camera issue.

Kaze explains his YouTube communication strategy: he hides level previews inside technical videos so viewers get proof of progress without a pure ‘spoiler preview,’ and because technical topics perform better and keep the audience from getting disgruntled about perceived lack of progress.

Regarding physical release, he says he is not allowed to sell cartridges; instead he plans a souvenir box and booklet with no Nintendo references, expecting that unofficial third parties may still make illegal cartridges (which would be expensive).

He lays out an art/design philosophy: he dislikes judging or creating art by rigid “principles” aimed at critics, preferring to start from the feeling he wants to evoke and then choose tools to produce that experience.
findings.quote: You think about what feeling I want to create, and then you look at your tools and how you can use your tools to create that feeling.

findings.summary: During F3 commentary, he pushes back on the recurring fear that showcases ‘hand Nintendo a takedown list,’ arguing that’s not how it works; he blames a popular talking point (“if you’re making a fangame, shut up about it”) for spreading paranoia, and claims anonymity/leaks and finishing before popularity spikes are more realistic dynamics.
findings.quote: If you make a fan game and you shut up about it and you don't show anyone, you C&D'd yourself.

biobak.summary: Kaze credits Biobak with the idea/model for upgraded ‘fuzzies’ enemies wearing protective gear (an iteration on enemies reminiscent of Lost Impact).
Kaze says he hopes Biobak will rework ‘Koopa/Cooper Carnival’ and frames it as the current plan.

badub.summary: Kaze mentions the Bowser office and Bowser elevator now have songs available (he notes the office is missing its song in-game at the moment but the tracks exist), implying ongoing music integration progress.

zeina.summary: Zeina is referenced throughout as present in chat and at home; Kaze notes Zeina’s mom is helping with the newborn, and he suggests Zeina could briefly cameo if she’s available.

findings.summary: Kaze mentions switching to “Sauraen’s profile,” which changes behavior/overlays (e.g., FPS display position), implying he’s using Sauraen-related tooling/configuration for performance profiling.

ZeroVolt appears in chat; Kaze discusses general audio import/compression options (MIDI/MP3/WAV/ADPCM and a hoped-for future compression improvement), but no concrete ZeroVolt-specific decision is made on-stream.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: This is what the N64 games could have looked like. You were robbed.
memorable_quotes.context: Reacting to running the hack on real N64 with modernized options like anti-aliasing and improved performance—framing the project as a corrective to historical constraints/choices.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: If you operate on principles, you make art for critics; you don't make art for the sake of it being experienced.
memorable_quotes.context: His broader creative philosophy for level aesthetics and why his palette/visual choices prioritize player feeling over formal ‘rules.’

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: If you make a fan game and you shut up about it and you don't show anyone, you C&D'd yourself.
memorable_quotes.context: Counter-argument to the common fear that publicity automatically triggers Nintendo takedowns; he reframes silence as self-sabotage.

key_stories.title: Fixing an N64-only broken pipe reveals deeper platform timing issues
key_stories.summary: Kaze celebrates an N64-specific bug fix when a previously nonfunctional pipe finally works on hardware, validating a week of bug-fix/performance cleanup. Immediately afterward, he notices the timer running far too fast, highlighting how hardware validation can uncover new edge cases (PAL timing, FPS-dependent logic).
key_stories.challenge: A gameplay element (pipe) that ‘never worked’ on real N64 and lingering hardware-specific correctness issues.
key_stories.process: He tests directly on N64 via his rapid switch-to-console workflow, verifies the pipe works, then observes secondary bugs like timer speed and considers platform timing differences.
key_stories.outcome: Pipe functionality is restored on N64, but timer logic remains suspect and becomes a follow-up investigation item.

key_stories.title: Course 13 blockout: make the platforming fun first, then solve visuals
key_stories.summary: Kaze iterates on a snowman-path section, noticing awkward wall-kicks and spacing, then simplifies the route and pulls geometry inward. He treats this as ‘platforming first’ work, planning to make it look good later (and partly avoiding N64 camera issues triggered by oversized spaces).
key_stories.challenge: Early platforming felt awkward and the environment scale risked triggering camera/render artifacts on N64.
key_stories.process: He playtests the route, adjusts obstacle parallelism/spacing, reduces awkward jumps, and re-scales layout to be more camera-safe while preserving the intended flow.
key_stories.outcome: He considers the platforming for the section “finished today” and plans to complete the visual/texturing work off-stream.

key_stories.title: Progress without spoilers: embedding level previews inside technical videos
key_stories.summary: Kaze explains he has to convince the audience the hack is progressing without publishing straightforward preview videos that either underperform or spoil surprises. His solution is to frame updates as technical deep-dives that incidentally show new content—both honest (it’s truly what he did) and strategically watchable.
key_stories.challenge: Pure previews get less engagement and can spoil content; but not showing anything risks viewers feeling the project stalled.
key_stories.process: He creates videos on technical topics (e.g., render matrices) and uses them to demonstrate a new feature in a level, making the level progress visible while providing a ‘reason to watch.’
key_stories.outcome: A repeatable communication/marketing approach that supports long development cycles and maintains audience trust/interest.
key_stories.key_quote: Whenever I make a preview, it's like: look how I used this new feature on the N64 to make this level.

open_questions.topic: Course 13 endgame schedule and remaining two levels
open_questions.context: Kaze says he hopes to finish Course 13 within a month, after which only two levels remain.
questions: What are the ‘two levels missing’ after Course 13—what are their themes and why are they last in the schedule?
What would have to go right (or could go wrong) for Course 13 to actually finish within a month?
Do the remaining levels depend on any unfinished engine features, art pipelines, or collaborators’ availability?

open_questions.topic: N64 camera/render artifacts in oversized areas
open_questions.context: Kaze sees camera issues on N64 and suspects the level being ‘too big’ causes it; he says he may need to invent a solution later.
questions: What exactly is the failure mode here (camera logic limits, fog/draw distance assumptions, culling, framebuffer clearing artifacts), and how reproducible is it?
What kinds of ‘invented solutions’ are on the table (area splitting, custom camera volumes, hard culling planes, portal rooms, streamed geometry)?
How often do these N64-only constraints force redesign of level scale compared to emulator testing?

open_questions.topic: Timer running too fast after N64 pipe fix (PAL/FPS coupling)
open_questions.context: After confirming an N64 pipe fix, Kaze observes the timer running far too fast and wonders about PAL behavior and unlimited-FPS interactions.
questions: What part of the code is still tied to frame rate (or the wrong timer source), and how did it slip through earlier tests?
Is the bug specific to PAL consoles, certain emulators, or the new performance tweaks/profile switch?
What’s your general approach to making game logic time-based rather than frame-based across N64/emu/unlocked FPS modes?

open_questions.topic: Physical ‘souvenir box/booklet’ plan and legal boundaries
open_questions.context: Kaze says he can’t sell cartridges, but wants to sell a box and booklet with no Nintendo references, anticipating third-party illegal carts will exist.
questions: What would the box/booklet include to still feel like a ‘complete set’ while avoiding Nintendo references—art, lore, credits, installation instructions?
Have you consulted anyone (legal or experienced creators) on where the line is for selling physical goods around a ROM hack?
Would you consider partnering with a non-Nintendo-branded flashcart/accessory maker, or is that too risky?
